In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

You can implement this in Julia using the `DateTime` type from the Dates package and the `throw` function to throw an error when a Date is passed instead of a DateTime. Here's how you could do it:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(date::Date)
    throw(ArgumentError("Expected DateTime but got Date"))
end
```
This function `timezone_bumper` will now work only for DateTime types and throws an error for any Date types. It increases the provided timestamp by 3 hours (the default), unless a different bump value is specified.
